All of the members of our Advisory
Committee had previously visited and inspected Mills Field, and two
the members, Colonel Brant and B. B. Mouton, had flom there

many occasions and were of the belief that many of the arguments
advanced by opponents of the field had their origin in the fact that
the fleld was only partially developed and was not due to any in-
herent faults in the field itself.
was satisfactory as an airport base
He all felt that the location
,and that, with the addition
of more land; the additional drainage of a large portion of the
proposed augmented field; the construction of proper runways and
satisfactory hangar space; satisfactory flood lighting for night
landings, and other improvements, the field would be a first-class
airport.
At this first meeting, however, Ir. Mouton earnestly
suggested that immediate steps be taken to secure definite knowledge
as to the possibilities of immediate vesting of title in the City
for the land occupied by Mills Fleld.
Both Colonel Brant and my-
self vigorously supported Ir. Mouton and stated that
as a citizens Advisory Committee, recommend that money be expended
for permanent improvements until me were certain that the field
could, either by purchase or by proper and legal condemnation, be
secured for the City within the very immediate future.
You there-
цооД
assured us that a gentleman's agreement had been entered into
with Mr. Mills whereby it was assured that purchase of the field
would be possible as soon as the City of San Francisco secured the
necessary money.
The study, subsequent action and recommendations
of this Committee, have been based upon this understanding that the
field could be purchased by the City and that any expenditures
would not be wasted on property to which the City of Sen Franoisco
could never have title.
Subsequent to the meeting of Mey 3rd, our Committee en-
gaged in correspondence and consultation with various experts re-
garding the situation at Mills Field, but held no further meetings
with your Airport Comittee of the Board of Supervisors, unt1l
your cal 1 for a second meeting.
This meeting was held on July 10th
at the Palace Hotel.
At this meeting the question of purchasing
the airport, or condemning it, was again the principal question
for discussion.
Colonel Brant suggested his willingness to
touch with Mr. Mills, through P.
Trubee Davidson, Assistant Secre-
tary of War; and I suggested my willingness to get in touch with
him, and you gave us assurance that the matter was being negotiated.
You then presented for the consideration of the Advisory
Committee a file, No. 531.14, called "Budget Items - 1929-1930*
in which the budget requirements of Mills Fleld for the current year
are set forth.
